I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  At the request of the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC), the capacity 
development  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Strengthening  the  Antipoverty  Effects  of  Social 
Assistance1 was included in the 2009 nonlending program of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) during the PRC country programming mission in December 2008. ADB undertook a 
reconnaissance mission in March 2009 and followed up with periodic discussions with the 
Ministry of Civil Affairs (MOCA), the project executing agency. Agreement was reached with the 
government, including the Ministry of Finance and MOCA, on the TA’s impact, outcome, outputs, 
cost and financing, implementation arrangements, and outline terms of reference for consulting 
services. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Social assistance is one of the major components of the social protection system in the 
PRC  and  a  key  to  ensuring  balanced  development  in  the  rapidly  changing  economic 
environment. The most important of the programs is the dibao or minimum living standards 
guarantee scheme. This social assistance scheme targets poor households with per capita 
income below locally determined poverty or social assistance lines. Dibao is the cash transfer 
program  upon  which  the  others,  such  as  medical  financial  assistance  and  educational 
assistance, are built. Begun in urban areas in 1999, urban dibao has been provided universally 
since 2002 and rural dibao since 2007. There are now 22 million–23 million beneficiaries of 
urban dibao. The rural dibao program has recently gone through a large expansion and has 
grown from covering 28 million beneficiaries in 2007 to 46 million beneficiaries in 2009.  
 
3.  Establishment and expansion of the dibao programs are significant achievements in the 
PRC’s efforts to reduce poverty in the country and provide a social safety net. However, issues 
relating to implementation, sustainability, and coverage remain important challenges. Rural 
areas of the PRC have made substantial progress in reducing poverty and since 1981 the rural 
poor population has fallen from 250 million to 14.79 million in 2007. Since the late 1990s, the 
rate of poverty reduction has slowed as certain populations, such as elderly and disabled 
households, are unable to benefit from development-based antipoverty programs that rely on 
employability as the key feature for lifting income levels. Funding for the program is provided by 
shared  arrangements  among  local  government  administrative  levels  (provincial,  prefecture, 
municipal, county, township, and village collectives). Because of funding limitations at the local 
level since 2007, the central government has subsidized local governments, especially those in 
the central and western regions.   
 
4.  Both programs face particular problems in implementation, sustainability, and assuring 
full coverage of vulnerable populations. Urban dibao faces challenges in providing adequate 
funding, incentives for beneficiaries to graduate from the assistance, addressing child poverty, 
and integrating dibao with other social insurance benefits and labor market policies. Rural dibao 
faces challenges in funding, targeting, and integrating the assistance with the newly introduced 
rural pension program, and medical and financial aid.   
 
5.  This TA is designed to address some of the major policy issues identified and provide 
recommendations for MOCA, which is responsible for the overall program of social assistance. 
The  Department  of  Social  Assistance  (DSA)  in  MOCA  is  responsible  for  the  design  and 
implementation  of  social  assistance  programs.  To  date,  MOCA  has  focused  its  efforts  on 
program promotion, guidelines, and field investigations on the performance of local programs 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB's website on 1 December 2009.

2   
and there is a need for further policy refinement. The major policy issues identified for further 
research and adjustment can be grouped into three categories: (i) sustainable financing and 
institutional arrangements, (ii) identification and targeting of the poor, and (iii) social inclusion.  
 
  1.  Sustainable Financing and Institutional Arrangements 
 
6.  Benefit rates and adjustment methods. Currently, benefit rates are determined by 
local governments, mostly using standard budgeting methods. In practice, many localities have 
determined benefit levels solely based on available local government income and financial 
constraints. In most localities, benefits are provided at a flat rate to all members in a household 
with equal shares and are usually too low to lift them out of poverty. There is a need to identify 
adequate and sustainable policies and systems for determining and adjusting benefit rates. 
 
7.  Adequate  benefit  graduation  incentives.  The  current  dibao  system  covers  a 
considerable proportion of the able-bodied population. MOCA has found that recipients are 
reluctant to graduate from assistance because it is associated with eligibility for related benefits 
such as medical and educational assistance and other preferential policies. The number of 
recipients exiting benefits has been negligible and there is a need for policy improvement in this 
area. 
 
8.  Performance  assessment. To date, little attention has been given to performance 
assessment, either from the perspective of internal efficiency of the system or from the impact at 
the household level. There is a need to determine appropriate policies and methods for both. 
 
  2.  Identification and Targeting of the Poor 
 
9.  Targeting  methods.  Local  governments  rely  on  means-testing  plus  community 
screening to select poor households based on the local poverty line. Measuring household 
incomes  has  proven  to  be  a  difficult  task  for  administrators  with  high  costs  and  frequent 
complaints from applicants over targeting errors. To avoid such problems, local civil affairs rely 
extensively  on  community-based  screening  for  selecting  potential  beneficiaries.  Efforts  by 
MOCA  to  ensure  transparency  in  this  process  have  yielded  results,  but  it  is  clear  that 
overreliance on this methodology is not a long-term solution. There is a need to refine targeting 
methodologies and establish clear policies. 
 
10.  Marginal poor. Eligibility for dibao provides access to other subsidies such as education 
assistance and medical financial assistance. For households that are just above the poverty 
level and therefore eligible for dibao, the inability to access the other benefits may actually mean 
that they fall below the consumption levels of dibao beneficiaries. This issue has been raised by 
several studies and there is an urgent need for investigation and policy recommendations on 
specific criteria and benefits for the marginal poor.  
 
  3.  Social Inclusion 
 
11.  Child poverty. A neglected issue in the PRC, child poverty has only begun to receive 
attention from the government recently. The World Bank assessment of poverty and inequality 
found that children, particularly girls, are more likely to be poor than the elderly.2 Increased 
vulnerability and risks for children have been recognized such as child trafficking, street children, 
                                                 
2  World  Bank.  2009.  From  Poor  Areas  to  Poor  People:  China’s  Evolving  Poverty  Reduction  Agenda. 
Washington, DC.

3 
child laborers, and left-behind children3 but there is general awareness that social protection for 
children is inadequate and relevant policies are absent—especially for children living in poor 
households. There is a need for the dibao system to consider the special needs of children in 
policy design and to coordinate work with stakeholders such as the State Council Leading 
Group  Office  of  Poverty  Alleviation  and  Development,  the  United  Nations  Children’s  Fund 
(UNICEF), and Plan International. 
 
12.  Links to related ADB technical assistance. The TA is directly linked to the PRC 
country partnership strategy (2008–2010), which places emphasis on inclusive growth and 
balanced development.4 The TA builds on findings and partnerships established in the ADB TA 
for  Facility  for  Policy  Reform  and  Poverty  Reduction  (subproject  1.4),  which  focused  on 
operational  mechanisms  for  rural  dibao  and  medical  financial  assistance.5 The  TA  will  be 
conducted in collaboration with the subproject on application of international best practices of 
social welfare reforms to social assistance policy in the PRC, which is being funded under ADB 
TA for Facility for Policy Reform and Capacity Building III.6 It will also seek to share findings and 
recommendations with ADB TA for Rural Pension Reform and Development.7 The TA will 
expand on these previous and current research efforts, and provide policy recommendations to 
strengthen the antipoverty functions of social assistance programs in the PRC. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
13.  The TA will build on the results of ADB-funded TA (footnote 5), which was carried out by 
MOCA in 2008 and led to the design of specific guidelines for improving rural social assistance 
programs. This current TA will strengthen the antipoverty functions of the social assistance 
programs in the PRC. This will be achieved through (i) case studies on current programs of 
selected counties or cities on sustainable financing, institutional arrangements, identification and 
targeting of the poor; and (ii) survey research on child poverty in select counties and cities. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact of the TA will be strengthened antipoverty functions of social assistance 
programs in the PRC. The outcome of the TA will be the policy recommendations proposed by 
MOCA adopted by the State Council. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA outputs will be (i) policy or implementation recommendations on measures and 
mechanisms  for  improving  social  assistance  in  the  PRC,  and  (ii)  widely  disseminated 
publications on key TA findings and recommendations. The recommendations will be drawn 
from the analysis and assessment of issues covering (i) sustainable financing and institutional 
arrangements, (ii) identification and targeting of the poor, and (iii) social inclusion. Three reports 
will be produced on the key issues of findings from the case studies in select areas and the 
survey analysis and findings on social inclusion and child poverty. A policy note for decision

makers presenting key findings and major policy and implementation recommendations of the 
TA will be shared with decision makers at the national and local levels, and a final conference 
will widely disseminate and discuss the results. A final report will bring all of the outputs together 
and provide an executive summary of the TA findings. 
 
16.  The TA will be implemented in three phases over an 18-month period. Phase 1 lasting 
3 months will comprise background research to (i) review current policies and strategies of 
implementation  for  each  of  the  key  issues,  (ii)  identify  international  best  practice  options, 
(iii) outline the methodologies to be used, and (iv) select the counties and cities for conducting 
the case studies and survey. An inception workshop will be held within the first month of the TA 
to discuss the initial sites, proposed methodologies, project teams, and anticipated outputs. 
Phase 2 will last for 12 months and will (i) undertake the case studies in selected counties and 
cities, and (ii) conduct the survey on child poverty. Technical working groups representing a 
range of stakeholders will be organized for each of the key topics. An ADB internal review group 
comprising  team  leaders  from  the  other  associated  TA  and  technical  experts  will  provide 
guidance and review of documentation. Phase 2 will include a series of workshops on each of 
the topics to present findings and receive feedback, guidance, and agreement on the policy and 
implementation recommendations. Phase 3 lasting 3 months will (i) finalize all of the reports and 
policy  and  implementation  recommendations,  (ii)  hold  a  final  conference  on  findings  and 
recommendations, (iii) prepare the policy note for decision makers, and (iv) disseminate the final 
reports.  
 
17.  The  final  conference  will  invite  participants  from  relevant  local  government 
representatives,  key  ministry  officials,  development  partners  and  research  organizations 
operating in the PRC, and others to share the TA findings and recommendations. A final report 
of the conference will be produced. All outputs will be provided in English and Chinese, and 
translation and publication costs will be included in the research costs. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $400,000 equivalent, of which $350,000 equivalent will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF—others). The 
government will finance the remaining $50,000 equivalent to cover the TA office and equipment 
(e.g., computers), office communications, and remuneration and per diem for counterpart staff. 
Tentative cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  MOCA has been a partner of ADB for several ADB-funded TA projects. MOCA is an 
experienced  and  capable  executing  agency.  DSA  has  been  the  implementing  agency  for 
previous  ADB  TA  projects.  Detailed  institutional  assessment  will  be  conducted  during  TA 
implementation.  DSA  will  provide  a  suitably  furnished  office  with  computers,  utilities,  and 
telecommunication access (including broadband internet connection), materials, maps, data, 
and documents as required under the TA, and will cover the cost of office utilities for the 
consultants. DSA will designate a TA focal point and will organize an expert steering committee 
group of invited national experts, who will review the inception, workshop, and final reports of 
the consultants and will participate in the final conference. The TA consultants will incorporate 
suggestions  of  the  expert  review  group  into  the  final  TA  reports.  DSA  will  also  organize 
institutional arrangements and coordinate local staff for the action research in selected counties 
and cities.

5 
20.  A total of 28 person-months of consulting services (two international consultants for 
3 person-months  and  three  national  consultants  for  25  person-months)  will  be  required. 
Consultants will have expertise in (i) design of social assistance programs and policies including 
benefit rates, targeting, and monitoring and evaluation; (ii) in-depth knowledge of existing social 
assistance  programs  in  the  PRC,  institutional  frameworks,  and  monitoring  and  evaluation 
systems; and (iii) poverty in the PRC, including issues pertaining to marginal poor and child 
poverty. Two national consultants will serve as the team leader and deputy team leader. The 
consultants will be responsible for producing the TA’s outputs and deliverables effectively and 
on time, and for organizing and carrying out all TA activities including the technical working 
groups, survey, and policy note. Technical working groups for each of the themes will be 
established by MOCA, with inputs from the consultants and ADB. Membership will be made up 
of relevant government ministries, local agencies, and development partners such as UNICEF, 
Plan International, and others. The consultants will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). ADB will create an 
internal review group of technical experts and team leaders responsible for TA on similar 
themes such as rural pensions. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
21.  In dialogue with MOCA and/or DSA, ADB will recruit individual national and international 
experts to provide inputs as formal consultants, short-term resource persons, and task-specific 
experts. ADB will endorse the terms of reference, including the duration and expected results. 
All  procurement  under  the  TA  will  be  carried  out  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). Individual consultants will be chosen based 
on their academic qualifications and relevant work experience. The proceeds of the TA will be 
disbursed in accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.8 To facilitate 
implementation, ADB may establish an advance facility for MOCA and/or DSA as needed, 
and/or utilize direct payment (e.g., for workshop venues). 
 
22.  Dissemination of results will be key to the success of the TA. The TA results and policy 
recommendations will be disseminated in a policy note for decision makers. In addition, reports 
on each of the main issues will be prepared, discussed at the workshops, and disseminated. A 
final TA report with executive summary of all findings will also be prepared.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $350,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Strengthening the Antipoverty Effects of 
Social Assistance, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of five consultants for a total of 
28 person-months  consisting  of  two  international  consultants  (3  person-months)  and  three 
national  consultants  (25  person-months)  over  18  months  during  TA  implementation.  The 
consultants will perform their tasks in close consultation with the Ministry of Civil Affairs (MOCA) 
as the executing agency and the Department of Social Assistance (DSA) as the implementing 
agency, and other responsible provincial and local government departments and agencies, to 
ensure full acceptance of the outcome of the TA. The consultants shall produce the following in 
both English and Chinese: (i) the main TA report, (ii) technical reports on the key issues outlined 
in the proposal, (iii) policy note for decision makers, (iv) conference report, and (v) executive 
summary of the main TA report. All consultants shall be familiar with social assistance programs 
in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 
2.  The  consultant  team  will  arrange  all  the  necessary  translations  needed  for  the  TA 
activities. The necessary documents for translation into English include policy documents in 
Chinese needed for the desk review and design of the field survey. Interpretation services shall 
be arranged on demand, including services for an international consultant, review mission of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), and workshops. 
 
3.  Consultants will have expertise in (i) design of social assistance programs and policies 
including benefit rates, targeting, and monitoring and evaluation; (ii) in-depth knowledge of 
existing social assistance programs, institutional frameworks, and monitoring and evaluation 
systems; and (iii) poverty statistics and poverty reduction programs and issues in the PRC, 
including issues pertaining to marginal poor and child poverty. The two national consultants will 
serve as the team leader and deputy team leader. The consultants will be responsible for 
producing the TA’s outputs and deliverables effectively and on time and for organizing and 
carrying out all TA activities including the survey and policy note. 
 
A.  Team Leader and Expert on Social Assistance Financial and Institutional Systems 
and Policies in the PRC (national, 10 person-months) 
4.  The team leader will 
(i)  coordinate with the deputy team leader in submitting to MOCA, DSA, and ADB 
an inception report within 1 month after the start of the TA; the report will contain 
(a) a work plan detailing each team member’s inputs (to be updated periodically 
as needed), (b) an outline of the main TA report and schedule, and (c) the design 
and plans for conducting the action research and survey on child poverty; 
(ii)  work  with  the  deputy  team  leader  to  ensure  a  clear  delineation  of  the 
responsibilities  among  team  members  and  national  and  local  government 
counterparts in the preparation, implementation, and other follow-up work for the 
TA survey, reports, workshops, seminars, and other TA activities; 
(iii)  work with the deputy team leader to ensure (a) the implementation of the TA 
according to the terms of reference and any subsequent instructions or guidance 
that may be provided by MOCA, DSA, or ADB; and (b) the timeliness and quality 
of the consulting team’s outputs and deliverables; 
(iv)  be  responsible  for  the  comprehensive  assessment  of  the  social  assistance 
system  and  capacity  in  selected  counties  and  towns  for  the  case  studies, 
investigating particular options for improving the benefit rates and adjustments, 
methods for targeting and identification of assistance schemes, and targeting for 
the marginal poor;

recommendations,  (b)  a  policy  note  for  decision  makers,  and  (c)  a  final 
conference report; and 
(xiii)  be responsible for preparing and finalizing publications based on the TA outputs 
and TA reports. 
 
B.  Deputy Team Leader and Specialist on Social Protection Programs and Policies in 
the PRC (national, 10 person-months) 
5.  The consultant will 
(i)  coordinate with the team leader in submitting to MOCA, DSA, and ADB an 
inception report within 1 month after the start of the TA, which will contain (a) a 
work plan detailing each team member’s inputs (to be updated periodically as 
needed), (b) an outline of the main TA report and schedule, and (c) the design 
and plans for conducting the action research and survey on child poverty; 
(ii)  work with the team leader to ensure a clear delineation of the responsibilities 
among team members and national and local government counterparts in the 
preparation, implementation, and other follow-up work for the TA survey, reports, 
workshops, seminars, and other TA activities; 
(iii)  work with the team leader to ensure (a) the implementation of the TA according 
to the terms of reference and any subsequent instructions or guidance that may 
be provided by MOCA, DSA, or ADB; and (b) the timeliness and quality of the 
consulting team’s outputs and deliverables; 
(iv)  in  collaboration  with  the  relevant  international  expert,  be  responsible  for  the 
action  research  on  targeting  methodologies,  recommendations  for 
implementation, and policy changes; 
(v)  in collaboration with the team, analyze the findings from the child poverty survey 
and collaborate on recommendations for adjustments to benefits and targeting 
methodologies for children; and

Appendix 3  11 
(vi)  work with the team on recommendations for performance assessment indicators 
and methodologies. 
 
C.  Specialist on Child Poverty (national, 5 person-months) 
6.  The specialist will 
(i)  under  the  guidance  of  the  team  leader  and  in  discussion  with  the  other 
consultants, design the child poverty survey; 
(ii)  decide with the team on sites for application; 
(iii)  lead the survey team (conduct necessary training, oversee logistics, data entry, 
analysis, etc.); 
(iv)  be responsible for survey analysis, findings, and key recommendations; 
(v)  liaise with the State Council Leading Group Office of Poverty Alleviation and 
Development, the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), Plan International, 
and other stakeholders working on child poverty in the PRC to integrate new 
research, validate findings, and recommendations; 
(vi)  be responsible for leading the workshop on child poverty and writing the draft 
report; and 
(vii)  with the team leader, finalize the final report and recommendations. 
 
D.  Specialist on Social Protection and Targeting (international, 1.5 person-months) 
7.  The specialist will 
(i)  have experience working in the PRC on social protection programs and policy 
formulation; 
(ii)  in coordination with the team leader and consulting team, serve as a resource 
person on best practice international experience with targeting methodologies for 
social assistance; 
(iii)  through videoconference, internet, or other means, provide intermittent guidance 
to the action research teams on the identification of key questions, methodology, 
and design of the child poverty survey; 
(iv)  review reports and provide comments on targeting, identification of marginal poor, 
and child poverty social assistance needs; and 
(v)  participate in the final conference. 
 
E.  Specialist on Social Assistance Finance and Institutional Assessment 
(international, 1.5 person-months) 
8.  The specialist will 
(i)  have experience working in the PRC on social protection programs and policy 
formulation; 
(ii)  in coordination with the team leader and consulting team, serve as a resource 
person on best practice international experience with social assistance finance 
and institutional assessment; 
(iii)  through videoconference, internet, or other means, provide intermittent guidance 
to the action research teams on the identification of key questions, benefit rate 
adjustment, and design of performance assessment methodologies; and 
(iv)  review  reports  and  provide  comments  on  benefit  rates  and  adjustment  and 
performance assessment proposed methodologies and policy recommendations.
